Union for a Democratic Alternative Party candidates boycott voting in elections, believing the process is corrupt or rigged against them. The candidates also held rallies encouraging their supporters to do the same.

assoc_actor_1: UMD: Union for Democratic Movements; UAD: Union for Democratic Change
notes: The UAD and UMD political parties protest the regime and majority political party. Police violently disperse them. One police officer, one protester killed.
The opposition Union for a Democratic Alternative holds a protest against President Guelleh's bid for a third term. Elections will be held April 2011.

On 5 February 2023, young citizens organized a protest in As Eyla (As Eyla, Dikhil) and called for the respect of their socio-economic and political rights. They also called for decent lives, employment and the respect for fundamental freedoms.

On 2 February 2023, young unemployed citizens organized a protest in the Arhiba neighborhood of Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti) and denounced the unemployment in the region. Djibouti Police Forces intervened and wounded several protesters.

On 5 March 2023, Afar and Somali rioters clashed in Dikhil, Bakere and As Eyla (As Eyla, Dikhil) for unknown reasons, leading to 3 deaths and injured people. Fatalities split across three events, coded to 1.

On 5 March 2023, Afar and Somali rioters clashed in Dikhil, Bakere (As Eyla, Dikhil) and As Eyla for unknown reasons, leading to 3 deaths and injured people. Fatalities split across three events, coded to 1.

On 5 March 2023, Afar and Somali rioters clashed in Dikhil (Dikhil, Dikhil), Bakere and As Eyla for unknown reasons, leading to 3 deaths and injured people. Fatalities split across three events, coded to 1.

actor2: FRUD: Front for the Restoration of Unity and Democracy
notes: Soldiers pushed away FRUD forces, including FRUD forces crossing from Ethiopia, on Yager mount in an attack on 15 August, leading to some injuries among soldiers.

actor2: FRUD: Front for the Restoration of Unity and Democracy
notes: FRUD forces attacked government soldiers at Margoita camp, leaving soldiers with injuries and stealing armaments.

assoc_actor_2: MRD: Movement for Democratic Renewal and Development
notes: On 13 April 2023, Movement for Democratic Renewal and Development (MRD) opposition party coordinator in Europe was arrested while arriving to the airport in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti) by Djiboutian Police Forces, who arrested him for a week. He was then expelled out of the country.

Around 2 May 2023 (as reported), rioters killed at least 4 ethnic Oromo immigrants and injured unknown number of people in Ariba, Umbuli, and Kartiya neighbourhoods (Djibouti city, Djibouti). The violence started following interpersonal fighting between two people.

On 30 April 2023, rioters attacked migrants and vandalized their shops in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti) following the expulsion of migrants (principally from Ethiopia) operated by Djibouti police and military Forces.

Other: On 30 April 2023, police and military forces of Djibouti arrested thousands of migrants in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti) following the looting of shops. They also escorted them back to the borders.

assoc_actor_2: RADDE: Rally for Action, Democracy and Ecological Development
notes: On 2 July 2023, Djibouti Police Forces arrested an opposition politician and several actors and singers, affiliated to the Rally for Action, Democracy and Ecological Development (RADDE) (coded to Djibouti, Djibouti), following their publishing of a parody video where they appear wearing the military uniform.

On 10 September 2023, teachers organized a protest in front of the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training's gate in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti) to denounce unjustified deductions from their salaries.

notes: Sacked police officer leads mutiny against ruling regime
Police break up peaceful protest against election irregularities and injure civilians
Landmine explosion kills police in north of country; no group claimed responsibility but likely the work of FRUD or other Afar militia
On 3 March 2024, a soldier killed a man near Torabora in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti) who was transporting contraband cigarettes.
On 24 May 2024, Djibouti Police Forces arrested 150 rioters in Arhiba and Salines Ouest neighborhoods in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti) following violence in the neighborhoods.

Other: On 4 October 2024, the Djibouti government offered the Ethiopian government 100pc of management rights over the port of Tadjourah (coded to Djibouti, Djibouti) in order to defuse rising tensions between Ethiopia and Somalia. This initiative comes as an offer to give direct sea access to the Ethiopian landlocked country.
Other: On 1 October 2024, boat operators forced individuals to jump off two boats carrying 310 migrants from Yemen to Djibouti close to Obock (Obock, Obock). 46 civilians were killed.
On 21 October 2020, the Government of Djibouti announced the closure of its borders for 15 days as measure to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

On 1 August 2021, Afar and Issa ethnic groups clashed in PK12 and Warabley neighborhoods in Balbala (Djibouti, Djibouti). At least 3 people were killed and twenty were injured, and two hundred fifty houses were set on fire.
On 1 August 2021, Afar and Issa ethnic groups clashed in Arhiba neighborhood in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti).
On 1 August 2021, the Djiboutian police opened fire on Afar demonstrators in Arhiba neighborhood in Djibouti (Djibouti) who were denouncing the attacks on their homes by Issa militia.

On 13 May 2022, citizens affiliated to an opposition party (party unknown) demonstrated in Djibouti city (Djibouti, Djibouti). A protester was taken to an undisclosed location by assumed police forces.
On 21 November 2024, police forces arrested 490 illegal migrants in several neighborhoods in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti) and transferred them to the Najad district during a large scale campaign.

Weapons seizure: On 16 December 2024, Djibouti Gendarme and customs officers intercepted more than a hundred daggers following an operation against weapons trafficking. Unknown location coded to Djibouti (Djibouti).

On 8 June 2024, at around 2:30 am Sanaa time, Houthi forces fired 2 missiles likely targeting the MSC Tavvishi container ship (IMO: 9189366) in the Gulf of Aden that fell inland in North Djibouti (coded to Moulhoule, Obock) claiming affiliation with companies in violation of the Houthi ban to call at Israeli ports. There were no fatalities or injuries as the missiles likely impacted an uninhabited area. Houthi forces have been labeling MSC ships as 'Israeli' possibly because of the dual Swiss-Israeli citizenship of one of MSC's co-founder and co-owner.

Six passengers were injured Sunday by an explosion on a freight and passenger train traveling between Djibouti and Ethiopia close to the junction at Daasbyo, some 75 kilometres (47 miles) south of Djibouti city

On 14 May 2018, a youth demonstration over the results of a career recruitment drive for a newly constructed port led to clashes with police in Tadjourah. 80 people were arrested and released later on. The youth blocked roads, stoned the security forces and ransacked the Regional Council offices.
On 30 December 2012, Djiboutian security forces fired on peaceful young demonstrators in the city of Obock, killing a 14 year-old and seriously injuring many others

actor1: FRUD: Front for the Restoration of Unity and Democracy
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Djibouti (1999-); Police Forces of Djibouti (1999-); Civilians (Djibouti)
notes: On 14 January 2021, FRUD militants simultaneously attacked a police commissariat, gendarmerie and a military camp with indirect fire (mortar or rocket attack) in Tadjourah (Tadjourah). One gendarme was killed and a civilian was injured during the attack.

Other: On 27 October 2025, the National Assembly unanimously voted to lift the presidential age limit in Djibouti (Djibouti, Djibouti), allowing the current president to run for a sixth term in the upcoming April 2026 election.
